goal.ch:
This course aims to equip students with the tools to communicate effectively in everyday contexts while building a solid grammatical and lexical foundation.
Students are expected to learn how to produce simple speech about everyday topics, including their personal experiences, goals, opinions, and basic descriptions or narratives. At this stage, perfect fluency or grammatical and lexical accuracy is not required. However, students must be able to communicate effectively, ensuring they are mostly understood in informal conversations while maintaining a logical flow of ideas. Pronunciation will also be a focus, with activities designed to help students refine their spoken French. Additionally, the course will delve into themes related to French-speaking cultures, communities, and countries.

outline.ch:
As stated above, the goal of this course is to help students produce coherent speech and manage simple dialogues in everyday situations.
Specifically, this semester will focus on mastering:
Consecutive subordinate clauses (subordonnées consécutives), such as “Il fait tellement froid que je ne peux pas sortir.“
Subordinating conjunctions (conjonctions de subordination), such as “parce que“, “comme“, “bien que“, “quand/lorsque“, and “si“.
Indirect questions (questions indirectes), such as “Je ne sais pas si elle aime lire.“ or “Je me demande à quelle heure il va arriver.“
Relative clauses (propositions relatives), such as “Le chat [que j‘ai vu] était gris“, or “L’hôtel [où on a dormi] était confortable.“
Linking words (mots de liaison) to make speech more fluid, such as “De plus“, “Cependant“, “Par ailleurs“, “Par conséquent“, and sequencers like “D‘abord… ensuite… enfin.“
Complex negation (négation complexe), such as “Je n‘ai rien vu“ or “Il n‘y a personne ici“.
Exclamation (exclamation), such as “Quel dommage !“, “C‘est super !“, or “Comme c‘est beau !“
The use of tutoiement or vouvoiement (informal and formal forms of address), “on“ as an equivalent to “nous“ in spoken French, and personal pronouns used as complements.
In terms of vocabulary, students will be expected to acquire essential words and phrases to enable them to understand and interact in most everyday situations, such as shopping, making reservations, or asking for information. Students will also learn strategies for adapting to situations where they encounter unfamiliar words. They will also practice expressing their ideas and opinions in a general and straightforward manner. This will be achieved through various activities. Students will deliver presentations on a subject of their choice. Weekly role-play dialogues, involving two or more students, will focus on material covered in the previous week. Additionally, students will prepare and practice short dialogues and monologues during class. As part of pronunciation practice, students may also be asked to submit recordings for personalized feedback.
